body:
Is this really an issue? The use case for the standalone JAR is to use it without any dependency management, isn't it? Right now there's only one POM: https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots/org/junit/platform/junit-platform-console/1.0.0-SNAPSHOT/

> Potential caused by by-passing
> http://imperceptiblethoughts.com/shadow/#default_java_groovy_tasks

Are we by-passing something?

True. But it should behave correctly, when resolved via Maven/Gradle/etc. I.e. it should not report any extra dependency.

Gradle docs hint at [maven_pom_generation](https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/maven_plugin.html#sec:maven_pom_generation) especially [:multiple_artifacts_per_project](https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/maven_plugin.html#sub:multiple_artifacts_per_project) ... combined with http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29392236/how-to-alter-dependencies-for-a-generated-artifact should do the trick: having two poms and have the standalone report no other dependency.

> Are we by-passing something?

Could be. See "_Configures the uploadShadow_" from the description ... which, I think, does not cover our new task at https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/junit-platform-console/junit-platform-console.gradle#L80 

Introducing a new module for "junit-platform-console-standalone" back then, might have been a cleaner solution.
Does Maven support different POMs for the same artifact ID?

Nope. "Maven can only deal with one artifact per project" from https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/maven_plugin.html#sub:multiple_artifacts_per_project and how to work around it in Gradle.

As we have the "" and "standalone" artifact, we can configure different poms for them.

Right now, those have the same artifact ID, only the classifier is different. If I read the workaround from the Gradle docs correctly, they actually change the artifact name. So, if that works in our case, I guess we could change `junit-platform-console-1.0.0-20170301.121026-403-standalone.jar` to `junit-platform-console-standalone-1.0.0-20170301.121026-403.jar`, right?

Mh. Yes? Not sure. :)

I think, with the filters you can also modify  (read: clear) the dependency list of a specific artifacts' generated pom file. Maybe. Like here: http://stackoverflow.com/a/42248185/1431016

> I think, with the filters you can also modify (read: clear) the dependency list of a specific artifacts' generated pom file. Maybe. Like here: http://stackoverflow.com/a/42248185/1431016

Yes, we need that piece as well!

But we also need to figure out how to create two different POMs that are consumable my Maven and Gradle. My guess is that we need two different artifact IDs, not just different classifiers.

issue.title: Introduce junit-platform-console-standalone module

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

Fixes #701 by moving standalone build, shadow, exec+check and Maven publish features into an own, dedicated sub-project. Here, the generated pom.xml doesn't contain any dependency to other archives.

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the JUnit Contributor License Agreement.

---

### Definition of Done

- [x] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [x] Method [preconditions](http://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [x] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [x] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests)
- [x] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](http://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/api/org/junit/platform/commons/meta/API.html)
- [x] Change is documented in the [User Guide](http://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](http://junit.org/junit5/docs/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)
- [x] All [continuous integration builds](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5#continuous-integration-builds) pass
